dc:description:
*CNTN4* encodes the neuronal cell adhesion molecule contactin 4. The relationship between *CNTN4* variants and neurodevelopmental disorders was first suggested in 2004, when Fernandez et al. reported a *de novo* balanced 3p26;10q26 translocation disrupting *CNTN4* in a boy with developmental delay and autism (PMID: 15106122). This translocation was not used as evidence because the contribution of other genes cannot be ruled out. Subsequent publications reported *CNTN4* variants, mainly copy number variants (CNVs), in individuals with autism, intellectual disability, delayed speech and motor development, seizures, and hypotonia (PMIDs: 21308999, 21658581, 24768552, 31422286). Due to the variable phenotypic spectrum, variants in *CNTN4* have been curated under the disease entity complex neurodevelopmental disorder. *CNTN4* CNVs have also been reported in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; these CNVs were not included in this curation.

Ten CNVs (three deletions and seven duplications involving only *CNTN4*), five missense variants, and one splice variant reported in 16 probands in seven publications (PMIDs: 21308999, 21658581, 24768552, 28714951, 29271092, 31422286; doi: [10.1016/j.rasd.2024.102399](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rasd.2024.102399)) are included in this curation. Many of the reported variants were inherited from unaffected parents and/or were present at high frequencies in gnomAD. Five individuals with autism spectrum disorder and intragenic duplications of *CNTN4* ranging from 56 to 300 kb were reported by Al-Mamari et al. (2024, doi: [10.1016/j.rasd.2024.102399](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rasd.2024.102399)); three duplications were *de novo*, while two were inherited from unaffected fathers. Since this report does not have a PMID, it cannot formally be documented in the curation at this time. Multiple other deletions and duplications involving *CNTN4* have been reported in large autism cohorts, but were not counted as evidence because they either overlapped multiple genes, were intronic, or overlapped only non-coding exons (e.g., PMIDs: 21658581, 24768552). Of note, *CNTN4* is not constrained for either loss-of-function variants (pLI = 0, gnomAD v4.1.0) or missense variants (Z = 0.64). Accordingly, a large case-control study investigating CNVs failed to find statistical evidence that *CNTN4* deletions were more frequent in children with intellectual disability compared to controls (PMID: 21841781). Since there is no convincing evidence that heterozygous *CNTN4* variants cause disease, all cases in this curation were scored 0. Although some authors have suggested that variants in *CNTN4* could be involved in neurodevelopmental disorders with reduced penetrance, more information is needed to delineate this.

Experimental evidence from knockout mouse models suggesting that disruption of *Cntn4* alters hippocampal synaptic plasticity and the dendritic arborization and spine density of pyramidal neurons (PMIDs: 33542194, 38745463) was not scored, given the lack of convincing genetic evidence. 

In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between *CNTN4* and autosomal dominant complex neurodevelopmental disorder has been disputed and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role *CNTN4* plays in this disease. This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on April 14, 2022 (SOP 9). It was reevaluated on August 7, 2024 (SOP 10). As a result of this reevaluation, the classification changed from Limited to Disputed due to a lack of convincing genetic evidence towards this gene-disease relationship.

curationReasonDescription: As a result of this reevaluation, the classification is disputed due to a lack of convincing genetic evidence towards this gene-disease relationship.

evidence.dc:description: In the absence of valid human genetic evidence, the experimental evidence was not scored. The mouse model studied is a homozygous knockout, whereas the CNTN4 variants reported in affected individuals are heterozygous.

Cntn4−/− mice show reduced levels of cell surface glutamate receptors in the cortex and hippocampus but increased levels in the striatum. In addition, Cntn4−/− mice show a downregulation of cell surface GABA receptors in the hippocampus and thalamus. These changes may be associated with altered excitatory and inhibitory synaptic transmission in specific brain regions.
evidence.rdfs:label: Glutamate and GABA receptor expression in Cntn4 KO mice

evidence.dc:description: In the absence of valid human genetic evidence, the experimental evidence was not scored.

Cntn4-/- and Cntn4+/- mice exhibited decreased synaptic potentiation in hippocampal slices, and abnormal dendritic arborization and spines of hippocampal CA1 neurons. Recognition memory and spatial memory were unaffected, but contextual fear conditioning was increased in heterozygous and homozygous KO mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Oguro-Ando mouse model

evidence.dc:description: In the absence of valid human genetic evidence, the experimental evidence was not scored. Note that this mouse model is a homozygous knockout, whereas the variants reported in affected individuals are heterozygous.

Cntn4-/- mice show a reduction in cortical thickness in the motor cortex, whereas changes in Cntn4+/- mice were not statistically significant. Alterations in the morphology and spine density of pyramidal neurons of the motor cortex were also observed in Cntn4-/- mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cortical changes in Cntn4 KO mice

evidence.dc:description: In the absence of valid human genetic evidence, the experimental evidence was not scored.

The consequences of heterozygous and homozygous disruption of Cntn4 in mice were studied on neurological, sensory, cognitive, and behavioral phenotypes at different developmental stages. Developmental neurological and cognitive screenings revealed no significant differences between genotypes. ASD-related behavioral domains, including social and restricted repetitive behaviors, were also unchanged in Cntn4-deficient mice. The impact of Cntn4-deficiency was found to be limited to increased startle response following auditory stimuli of high amplitudes in heterozygous and homozygous Cntn4-deficient mice and enhanced acquisition in a spatial learning task in homozygous mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Behavioral characterization of Cntn4-deficient mice

evidence.dc:description: Partial gene duplication (spanning exons 1-3 of CNTN4) with no evidence of pathogenicity. Inherited from the father who had normal developmental milestones but is described as having some autistic traits.

Variant is not scored because the gene is not constrained for missense variants, the variant is inherited from an unaffected parent, and is present at a high frequency (988/1612546 alleles (0.06%)) in gnomAD v4.1.

Cultured primary cortical neurons were transfected with WT and CNTN4 mutant vectors to assess the effect of variants in dendritic spine formation and neural activity. The G221D mutant was unable to promote spine growth, as observed in neurons overexpressing WT CNTN4. When examining calcium transients, the neurons overexpressing G221D had an altered frequency and amplitude compared to the control (Zhao et al. 2021, PMID: 34415325).
Gene is not constrained for truncating variants. Paternally inherited variant (no information about the father’s phenotype).
Gene is not constrained for truncating variants. Variant inherited from unaffected mother.
Variant is not scored because the gene is not constrained for missense variants, the variant is inherited from an unaffected parent, and is present 7 times in gnomAD v4.1

Variant is not scored because the gene is not constrained for missense variants, the variant is inherited from an unaffected parent, and is present at a high frequency (299/1614014 alleles (0.02%)) in gnomAD v4.1.

Cultured primary cortical neurons were transfected with WT and CNTN4 mutant vectors to assess the effect of variants in dendritic spine formation and neural activity. The N178D mutant was unable to promote spine growth, as observed in neurons overexpressing WT CNTN4. When examining calcium transients, the neurons overexpressing N178D had an altered frequency and amplitude compared to the control (Zhao et al. 2021, PMID: 34415325).
Partial gene duplication with no evidence of pathogenicity. Overlaps the upstream region of CNTN4 and exons 1-2.
Gene is not constrained for LoF variants, and the deletion is inherited from the unaffected father.
Gene is not constrained for truncating variants. Paternally inherited variant (no information about the father’s phenotype).
Variant is not scored because there is no functional evidence of pathogenicity and the gene is not constrained for missense variants. gnomAD v4.1: 1/44864 alleles.

Variant is not scored because the gene is not constrained for missense variants, the variant is inherited from an unaffected parent, and is present at a high frequency (48/1613978 alleles (0.003%)) in gnomAD v4.1.

Cultured primary cortical neurons were transfected with WT and CNTN4 mutant vectors to assess the effect of variants in dendritic spine formation and neural activity. The E331G mutant was unable to promote spine growth, as observed in neurons overexpressing WT CNTN4. When examining calcium transients, the neurons overexpressing E331G had an altered frequency and amplitude compared to the control (Zhao et al. 2021, PMID: 34415325).
